content:
lass="word-wrap-span">This is a by-lass="word-wrap-span">invitation lass="word-wrap-span">commentary in a series on “lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s lass="word-wrap-span">Future,” part of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist ’s lass="word-wrap-span">Open lass="word-wrap-span">Future lass="word-wrap-span">initiative, which aims to lass="word-wrap-span">foster a global conversation across lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ideological spectrum on vital issues. lass="word-wrap-span">You can comment here or on Facebook and lass="word-wrap-span">Twitter . lass="word-wrap-span">More articles can be found at lass="word-wrap-span">Economist.com/lass="word-wrap-span">Openlass="word-wrap-span">Future

lass="word-wrap-span">MORE lass="word-wrap-span">THAN 70 days after the first mass protest against the government’s “lass="word-wrap-span">extradition” bill on lass="word-wrap-span">June 9th, lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong continues to be lass="word-wrap-span">gripped by large-scale lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations and threats of fresh mobilisations to paralyse the airport and mass-transit railways. lass="word-wrap-span">Although the protest on lass="word-wrap-span">August 18th, which organisers claim was attended by 1.7m people, concluded peacefully, no end to the prolonged conflict is in sight.

lass="word-wrap-span">Earlier this month, tensions lass="word-wrap-span">escalated following pronouncements by senior officials at a meeting in lass="word-wrap-span">Shenzhen, just across the border in mainland lass="word-wrap-span">China, that the lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese government would not sit on its hands if the violence worsened and the situation got out of control. lass="word-wrap-span">Prior to that, the national lass="word-wrap-span">emblem at lass="word-wrap-span">China’s lass="word-wrap-span">Liaison lass="word-wrap-span">Office in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong had been lass="word-wrap-span">defaced with black paint by lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrators. On two separate occasions in the following days, the national flag was pulled off a harbour-side lass="word-wrap-span">flagpole and thrown into the water.

lass="word-wrap-span">Many feared that lass="word-wrap-span">China would not allow such lass="word-wrap-span">deliberate acts of provocation go unpunilass="word-wrap-span">Shed. lass="word-wrap-span">Footage of paramilitary police in lass="word-wrap-span">Shenzhen training for anti-riot lass="word-wrap-span">deployment lass="word-wrap-span">heightened lass="word-wrap-span">anxiety that direct lass="word-wrap-span">intervention by lass="word-wrap-span">China’s armed forces would be lass="word-wrap-span">inevitable.

lass="word-wrap-span">Under article 14 of the lass="word-wrap-span">Basic lass="word-wrap-span">Law, the special administrative lass="word-wrap-span">Region’s mini-constitution, the local government may, when necessary, ask for lass="word-wrap-span">assistance from the lass="word-wrap-span">People’s lass="word-wrap-span">Liberation lass="word-wrap-span">Army’s lass="word-wrap-span">garrison in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong in the maintenance of public order and disaster relief. Or lass="word-wrap-span">alternatively, lass="word-wrap-span">Under article 18, if the lass="word-wrap-span">Standing lass="word-wrap-span">Committee of lass="word-wrap-span">China’s lass="word-wrap-span">National lass="word-wrap-span">People’s lass="word-wrap-span">Congress decides that lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong is in a state of lass="word-wrap-span">emergency by reason of turmoil “which lass="word-wrap-span">endangers lass="word-wrap-span">National unity or security and is beyond the control of the government of the lass="word-wrap-span">Region”, it may issue an order applying the relevant lass="word-wrap-span">National lass="word-wrap-span">Laws in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong. lass="word-wrap-span">Either option would permit the direct lass="word-wrap-span">deployment of lass="word-wrap-span">China’s armed forces in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong.

lass="word-wrap-span">That is because leaders in Beijing are all too lass="word-wrap-span">keenly lass="word-wrap-span">aware lass="word-wrap-span">That, even though any direct lass="word-wrap-span">intervention would be legally lass="word-wrap-span">justifiable under the terms of the lass="word-wrap-span">Basic lass="word-wrap-span">Law, and in practice necessary for the purpose of stopping violence and restoring order, any such lass="word-wrap-span">intervention would be bound to be negatively portrayed by the international community as an “act of suppression of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s freedoms”.

lass="word-wrap-span">The reputational damage to lass="word-wrap-span">China as a responsible actor in lass="word-wrap-span">The international community, and as lass="word-wrap-span">The originator of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">innovative concept of “lass="word-wrap-span">One lass="word-wrap-span">Country, lass="word-wrap-span">Two lass="word-wrap-span">Systems”, would be too lass="word-wrap-span">costly for a lass="word-wrap-span">Country already lass="word-wrap-span">embroiled in a lass="word-wrap-span">geopolitical struggle with lass="word-wrap-span">The world’s most powerful democracy.

lass="word-wrap-span">Whether during the “lass="word-wrap-span">Occupy lass="word-wrap-span">Central” movement in the autumn of 2014, or in the current lass="word-wrap-span">confrontation, any lass="word-wrap-span">attentive observer would have noticed rhetoric on the part of the organisers strongly redolent of the language of the lass="word-wrap-span">June 4th victims. lass="word-wrap-span">Calls by students for dialogue with the top leader in the government’s lass="word-wrap-span">civic square, appeals by the mothers of protesters for the authorities not to “hurt their children”, tweets claiming “Oh my lass="word-wrap-span">God, the lass="word-wrap-span">Police are shooting at children!”, and so on, all appear to be attempts to portray the events in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong as violent suppression by an lass="word-wrap-span">intransigent government deaf to the demands of the people.

lass="word-wrap-span">Yet the way the lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong police have responded to the provocations stands in marked contrast to how their lass="word-wrap-span">forebears dealt with past violent protests, let alone the way mainland lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese authorities dealt with the protests in Beijing in 1989.

In 1966 in lass="word-wrap-span">The district of lass="word-wrap-span">Kowloon on lass="word-wrap-span">The north side of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong harbour, unrest was sparked by a proposed rise in lass="word-wrap-span">ferry fares but reflected simmering public anger. It lasted only four days, yet 93 rounds of live lass="word-wrap-span">ammunition, were fired resulting in one lass="word-wrap-span">killed and three lass="word-wrap-span">injured from lass="word-wrap-span">gunshot wounds; 1,200 lass="word-wrap-span">canisters of tear gas were fired; some 1,465 protesters were arrested and more than 300 were sentenced to prison. lass="word-wrap-span">The British-led joint police-military operations, supplemented by lass="word-wrap-span">auxiliary defence units, quashed lass="word-wrap-span">The riots in a matter of days, using overwhelming force.

No such option is available to the lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong government. By reason of being a special administrative region of lass="word-wrap-span">China, it has to be mindful of the frequent lass="word-wrap-span">allegations of undue lass="word-wrap-span">interference directed at lass="word-wrap-span">China. Its police have to be lass="word-wrap-span">extremely careful in their use of lass="word-wrap-span">Force. lass="word-wrap-span">For that reason, the police lass="word-wrap-span">Force has been criticised lass="word-wrap-span">For alternating between lass="word-wrap-span">abandoning its positions when it should have lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">intervened, and lass="word-wrap-span">For using lass="word-wrap-span">excessive lass="word-wrap-span">Force when such lass="word-wrap-span">Force was lass="word-wrap-span">deemed unnecessary by the public.

lass="word-wrap-span">Other than relying on the police, the government scored a significant victory recently in restoring order at its lass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">Airport by obtaining a court lass="word-wrap-span">injunction to prohibit unlawful and willful “obstructing or interfering with the proper use of the lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong lass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">Airport”. lass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps out of lass="word-wrap-span">awareness on the part of the protesters that they had gone too far in paralysing the lass="word-wrap-span">Airport, and possibly out of underlying respect for the authority of the court, the protesters eventually lass="word-wrap-span">dispersed peacefully, a welcome sign that the rule of law still commands substantial authority in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong.

I have no lass="word-wrap-span">crystal ball to predict when the present conflict will be brought to a close. LIHKG, the online platform for mobilising this supposedly lass="word-wrap-span">faceless and leaderless movement, remains as active as ever in organising. lass="word-wrap-span">Many sensitive dates, such as the fifth anniversary of the onset of the “lass="word-wrap-span">Occupy lass="word-wrap-span">Central” lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations on lass="word-wrap-span">September 26th, as well as lass="word-wrap-span">China’s lass="word-wrap-span">National lass="word-wrap-span">Day on lass="word-wrap-span">October 1st, loom as potent dates for renewed mass mobilisations.

lass="word-wrap-span">The riots which lass="word-wrap-span">convulsed lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong in 1967, which were inspired by lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Cultural lass="word-wrap-span">Revolution in lass="word-wrap-span">China, took eight months to quieten down. If “lass="word-wrap-span">external forces” are indeed involved in lass="word-wrap-span">The present conflict as in 1967, it may take a few more months before lass="word-wrap-span">The present turmoil is brought to a close.

As and when lass="word-wrap-span">The present turmoil finally comes to an end, lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong will lass="word-wrap-span">emerge a different city from its former self—lass="word-wrap-span">The authority of its government severely lass="word-wrap-span">battered, law and order and lass="word-wrap-span">The city’s reputation for safety badly damaged. lass="word-wrap-span">The police’s relationship with lass="word-wrap-span">The people, especially young people, will take years to repair.

As for the city’s future, it has much less cause for concern about direct, lass="word-wrap-span">forceful lass="word-wrap-span">intervention from the mainland, than from reports, just released, that the lass="word-wrap-span">Party leadership and the lass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">Council want to build neighbouring lass="word-wrap-span">Shenzhen into a “pilot lass="word-wrap-span">demonstration lass="word-wrap-span">Area of socialism with lass="word-wrap-span">Chinese lass="word-wrap-span">characteristics,” to better lass="word-wrap-span">implement the strategy to develop the Guangdong-lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong-Macau lass="word-wrap-span">Greater lass="word-wrap-span">Bay lass="word-wrap-span">Area, and to strengthen the lass="word-wrap-span">implementation of “lass="word-wrap-span">One lass="word-wrap-span">Country, lass="word-wrap-span">Two lass="word-wrap-span">Systems”.

lass="word-wrap-span">Are plans being made to lass="word-wrap-span">groom lass="word-wrap-span">Shenzhen as the new lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong? In view of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s declining economic importance to lass="word-wrap-span">China and its tendency to become a source of conflict, perhaps lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong should be more worried about lass="word-wrap-span">abandonment by lass="word-wrap-span">China than lass="word-wrap-span">intervention.

_____________

lass="word-wrap-span">Regina Ip is a member of the lass="word-wrap-span">Executive lass="word-wrap-span">Council and lass="word-wrap-span">Legislative lass="word-wrap-span">Council of lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong. lass="word-wrap-span">She was the lass="word-wrap-span">Secretary for lass="word-wrap-span">Security from 1998 to 2003.
